title: Will annual sales of electric vehicles in China reach 500,000 in 2016?
preds: "It is noteworthy that, from 2014-2016, the new energy market growth in the year-on-year decline, respectively, 290%, 202%, 102%. The future of new energy passenger car market growth rate will further slow down will become the norm"

http://www.autoblog.com/2016/12/29/china-far-ahead-of-us-europe-in-total-electric-vehicle-sales/
http://www.hybridcars.com/china-takes-lead-as-number-one-in-plug-in-vehicle-sales/
"Although there is wiggle room with December sales not counted, given present trends, it’s estimated China will finish with as many as 635,000-645,000 cumulative plug-in sales since 2010 – perhaps 20,000-30,000 more than Europe, and over 70,000 more than the U.S."
The China Association of Automobile Manufacturers reported that 337,000 new energy vehicles were sold in the country during the first 10 months of 2016 (+82%).

China is going to fall short with around 350,000 vehicles for 2016.
The final number will come in well short of 500K. My estimate is about 375K.
No, perhaps 350,000 this year, and 500,000 in 2017.

Sales are only 2/3rds of the way there through October, but November and December sales made up well over a third of the yearly sales in each of the past two years according to CAAM data.  While this seems suspect, it is a pattern and it might continue this year.  However, relative YoY growth has been slowing in each of the last monthly reports.  If the sales figures for November and December of this year equal those of last year then total sales will fall just a few thousand short of 500,000.  CAAM has never reported a YoY drop in sales.  As suspect as the year end numbers may be, there still seems to be a decent chance that they report the same thing again this year.

Things for you (and me) to ponder:

Based on the numbers at http://evobsession.com/baic-takes-gold-bronze-october-china/, Chinese sales of EVs are around 220,000 at the end of October. With 61 days left in the year and a uniform distribution of sales across the year, we should expect sales to cap out the end of the year just ahead of 250,000, or roughly half the prediction question. Accordingly, more than 500,000 total sales seems extremely unlikely.

Two things of interest, first, China is modeling a carbon quota much like "California" and the NEV industry is having problems.  What I found interesting is Chinese officials have acknowledged there is concern with the NEV scandal from earlier this year.  There is discussion about what to do with incentives and possible new policy.  I think the lack of NEV sales data on both the Mandarin and English sites reflects bad news for NEV.  The combination of a carbon plan and possible incentive changes may be the way China planners "save face" or rather the planners will advertise a purposeful deliberate decline and that will be the story versus the planners and government screwed up. http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/china-names-more-firms-in-car-scandal

"BEIJING, Sept 9 (Reuters) - China has accused more than 20 additional car makers, including Nissan and Hyundai , of breaking rules on green car subsidies, according to a state media report, widening a scandal over a $4.5 billion annual payout programme.
On Thursday, China's Ministry of Finance punished at least five car makers, accusing them of cheating its programme to subsidise electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles, receiving roughly 1 billion yuan ($150 million) in illegal subsidies."

The real question is will China reflect integrity in their reporting.  There seems to be a broad outside view that China will not meet the 500K in 2016.  This of course is how a western looks at this question.  How does a Chinese Government official or business official look at this question.  To help answer this I dived back into Chinese culture.  Specifically, "saving face -vs-  losing face".  In Chinese culture the chopstick relay race is a common fun game.  Read Jason's experience in a chopstick relay.  http://www.yoyochinese.com/blog/What-Does-Losing-Face-Mean-Importance-Face-Chinese-Culture

In 2012 Chinese consumers bought only 11.375 units of electric vehicules out of 19.3 million sold. This year, 2016, For the first seven months, the production and sales of new energy vehicles reached 215 thousand units and 207 thousand units respectively, increasing 119.8% and 122.8% year on year. To be specific, the production and sales of BEV reached 162 thousand units and 153 thousand units, increasing 156.4% and 160.9% year on year; and such figures for PHEV were both 54 thousand units, increasing 53.7% and 57.6% year on year.
The sales trajectory shows they have a very good chance of achieving this target in 2016.

Question relates to sales, not production. In 2016 to date, sales are running approximately 130% more than last year == 430K sales for the year.
Slow growth and continuing low oil prices make this look even less likely.

Less than 200k consumer NEVs sold in China in 2015.  Even though that was a 200% YOY increase, it seems like a big stretch to see 500k in 2016, especially given slower overall growth in China, which will drag down bus and other government purchases.

Thru May 2016, NEV sales are up 174% vs the same time period last year.  The average growth rate needed to hit the 500,000 mark by year end is ~43% each month for the rest of the year. Although sales are backend weighted--heavily favoring Nov/Dec, even applying a modest growth rate here (10%) and 99 percentage points slower growth for the other months (75%), you still end the year above 500,000. Therefore, in conclusion, i think it is highly likely that NEV sales will be greater than 500,000. My 98% is a function of embedded risks of further downside in the Chinese economy (1% on a risk-adjusted basis), and 1% for unforeseeable risk.
A quick Google search seems to indicate that electric vehicles have ~ doubled in China in the last year. Since there were ~ 300 k sold in 2015, it seems likely that the goal of 500 k will be reached.

If this is an official target and they're close by Q4, the government will find the need for a bunch of electric vehicles.
Sales are on pace to surpass 500,000, but that relies on a surge at the end of the year, like there was in 2015.
China seems to be on track to exceed this sales figure for the year.

Govt subsidies. Smog. Govt building charging stations. 10 year plan.

China is hosted ng the G20 summit and they are already posturing on lessening pollution (even if it's only during the summit).  Thus, the Chinese govt will put out a lot of incentives to increase electric car sales.  Plus, the Chinese auto industry will put out a cheaper copy of an electric vehicle that will push sales further up.

Looking at supply side and demand side constraints. On the supply side, battery production is constrained by availability of cobalt and lithium. The Chinese have supplied locked in for both and supply side should not be a problem. On the demand side, the Chinese car market is trending towards 22M units. To reach 500k sales ev,s will have to take slightly more than 2% of market share from 1.5% in 2015. Given the $150000 tax rebate on electric cars and immediate registration vs waiting in line for regular cars in cities, the economics work out for consumers and the demand should be there.

The Global EV Outlook 2016 study noted, "The year 2015 saw the global threshold of 1 million electric cars on the road exceeded, closing at 1.26 million [100 times more than in 2010]. This is a symbolic achievement highlighting significant efforts deployed jointly by governments and industry over the past ten years. In 2014, only about half of today’s electric car stock existed. In 2005, electric cars were still measured in hundreds."
This is a crude forecast; doing it more to learn the error of my ways!

I have to be careful to not go too inwards too quickly and start off with broad base questions.

Still don't see them near the their own target as the consensus does. Factor in the massive (@700 billion) in capital outflow, and I am not seeing much consumer confidence in China, let alone the need for a big ticket item such as a car, when there are already good substitutes available (a friend told me Beijing  transit carries over 3 million people a day for roughly thirty cents a ride). Factor in That the cost of a license can be as much as a car and that the infrastructure to maintain, charge EVs is still nascent...

Sales so far this year have been more than twice those of last year, which puts them well on pace to reach 500,000 which would be a 50% increase.  A large percentage of the purchases have occurred in the final few months of the year in each of the last two years.  This seems to be driven by local government purchases and government incentives, so it is possible that this trend isn't continued if their is a change in policies, but I think it is likely to continue.
There is a strong possibility, especially with the Govt. backing this initiative

CHina's economy is now growing at ~6% if you believe what they say.  Although Chinese are buying more and more cars, electrical vehicles are still too expensive and  impractical to own in China at this time.

I knew I shouldn't get involved in this question as the numbers were always questionable. My initial premise was that they would reach 350k cars and 150k buses (and that the buses were added in to the statistics at the end of the year, as the only way to explain the sudden jump from Oct 15 to FY15 production).
There are three other possibilities to explain that jump:
Fraud from car makers/dealers: http://www.chinapost.com.tw/china/china-business/2016/05/24/467070/Incentives-main.htm
Late reporting
Official manipulation of numbers to reach targets
So if I adjust my number for all three factors, fraud given the anti-corruption focus in china should reduce (-12%), late reporting should also reduce as companies get more sophisticated (-2%), and official reporting and the desire to hit target should bump probability up, but due to anti-corruption efforts not as much as historically (+8%).
Shaving a little from the consensus (70-80%) among people I follow to account for a slowing Chinese economy.

EV sales would need to more than triple from 2015. Certainly possible within a command & control economy, but would need to be a better result than devoting resources to other economic stimulus options
Chinese gouvernement promoting ev sales will help to reach 500000 sales!

with vehicles are scooters included, and in the big city is by law that you dont drive with a normal engine

I have reflected on American culture versus Chinese Culture in reference to failure.  The first observation is business corruption rankings of the USA which is 16 (low) versus Chinese business corruption rankings of China which is 83 (high).  As an American when I see corruption or wrongdoing I immediately overreact and want to put people in prison.  In China wrongdoing from an American perspective is ...well ok.  Also The American way of business is established versus Chinese way of business is evolving.  I read an article that said Chinese business and government types have fear of failure.  They call this "saving face".  Failing is not culturally acceptable in China.  I bring all this up because I have hung my hat on the corruption in the EV market reporting of new EVs and how this will destroy the EV market.  After researching Chinese culture I now assume that the EV corruption will be chalked up as an "isolated incident" or "road bump" and press on.  Also Chinese culture will take a generation to change if at all.  All this said I still think the 500K will be close.  The outside view broad market is not looking good.  OTOH I acknowledge that the Chinese government has the 2020 goal and they want to accomplish this.  So I think the Chinese will cut the cheaters out and put good money towards groups that perform and actually build EVs.  So unless the market collapses or there is revelation of some sort of complete Chinese market wide fraud the 500K will be met.  Please punch holes in this if I'm wrong.

I'm adjusting from 3% to 21%.  First, consensus is 85% I hope the consensus forecast is not reflective of the blind leading the blind.  Second, I want my forecast to remain within sprinting distance if I determine I'm wrong.

After reviewing the CAAM numbers, it still looks like the annual sales of electric vehicles in China will fall short of 500,000.  It would take a large increase in sales later in the year to reach this threshold - not impossible, just unlikely.

90,529 sold through April [http://www.caam.org.cn/AutomotivesStatistics/20160513/1605191152.html], meaning 410k is needed in 8 months, or over 50k/month. That would be more than a 100% increase from the first four months of 2016. I don't see it happening.

500k / 12months = 41,666 cars per month.    From January through April 90k were sold, or 22,632 per month http://www.caam.org.cn/AutomotivesStatistics/20160513/1605191152.html.      Adding the lack of subsidies and the country's credit bomb, I'm saying this can't happen.

Chinese EV subsidies has fueled fraud in late 2015.  China cut EV subsidies in Dec 2015.  This is why Dec 2016 had a rush of last minute EV "sales".  Which prompted the investigation and revelation of fraud.  The new decreased subsidies are in now. I'm leaning towards no. Last year, sales were 330,000. Growth has to be 1.5x to reach 500k. Although the Jan/Feb months increased 1.7x YoY, that was from relatively small numbers. China would have to sell 1.5x over what they produced in the latter part of 2015 each month, and so far they aren't reaching those levels. Furthermore, there are reports of economic slow down in China.

Sales have to grow about 50% from 2015 to reach 500k.  Monthly growth (when compared with the comparable month the previous year) has been well over that number for many months in a row, including in January and February of this year.  It seems unlikely to reverse to me that trend which has been going on for more than a year and has many forces pushing it - new and better technology, government incentives, increasing popularity of EVs - unless there is a huge economic maelstrom.  There are so many forces all pushing in the direction of high-growth, it is difficult to envision any force strong enough to overcome all of those forces such that the sales growth dramatically changes.  Again, the one force that could be strong enough is a severe economic downturn.

My previous posts focused on the outside view of tis question.  Focusing on US auto market, US EV market, auto stock technical analysis, and China stock market.  I was looking for inside view questions to ask and @Censusguyz asked about China EV restrictions.  This question go me to do some research and I found some information by Lux Research;
There is a strong push for EV in China right now and the supply of EV related materials is tight. Plus the new round of money supply will stimulate the economy.

Chinese government five year plan (FYP) for 2016-20 seems clear - major move to technological energy (solar / wind) plus homegrown (coal / shale) plus indigenous higher-end products (up-rated tea-pot refineries buying up low-price crude to generate local gasoline) - all in service of reducing energy importation on (erratic / non-aligned) gulf states. 100plusGW target for solar by 2020, same for wind, leads to ca 15% derived energy from technology where they are leaders (PV panels) and wind turbines by that date. That sets the trend - less need for imports, growing leadership in technological energy (not fuel-based i.e. oil / gas), and side effects of less CO2 in the long-run (city-smog). Remember - technology costs reduce with time e.g. Swanson's law, extractive costs increase. Key lesson China taking to heart. See for example, and then follow the lines of reasoning :  http://blogs.ft.com/nick-butler/2016/04/18/will-china-transform-the-worlds-energy-market/
EV growth fits squarely into this strategic long game - specific target, they are investing in subsidies for infrastructure as well as EVs, and they are making EVs quickly and cheaply, so definition of EV may get stretched, but world will catch on that making good-enough EV and quick infrastructure build is the way to make any state - not just China - capable of generating key baseload of energy from technology and not imported fuel. See anything in the last 2 years by Bloomberg New Energy finance. As an aside. this is potentially ideology-free energy development (e.g. solar / wind aggressive investment in - wait for it - Texas). As solar / wind reach tipping point for cost / MWh, as they have in certain areas, commercial scale electricity from solar / wind will increasingly be seen as technological-based energy, not fuel-based. Once erected, solar / wind projects are essentially fuel free, they are modular so pay-back can be relatively quick, and they benefit from technology learning / cost curves, unlike extractive fuel projects, except in certain countries, or fracking in US which benefits from the same technology improvements over time via repetition. China has leadership in this "new" energy, and EVs will sit square within that. Zero CO2 and energy independence are by-products of switching to technology-based energy, not the ideological rationale. Upping my analysis to 96%, as I suspect that is Chinese planning basis.

Sales of SUVs, seen as the safest option on China's rough, chaotic roads, soared 52 percent last year. That helped the overall market grow 7.3 percent — a sliver of its 45 percent peak in 2009 — even though car and minivan sales sagged.
"Ten years ago, no one wanted an SUV because it was considered to be a bulky truck for peasants," said Michael Dunne, a consultant on Chinese auto market strategy. "Now the cool factor has kicked in and SUVs are super-hot in the China market."Overall sales growth is likely to fall further this year to 6 percent after economic growth fell last year to a 25-year low...When that failed to work fast enough, communist leaders extended support to independents such as BYD Auto, an electric vehicle maker, and Geely Holding Group, which bought Sweden's Volvo Cars in 2010 with support from state banks. 
Global automakers were required to help state-owned partners create Chinese brands such as GM's Baojun and Nissan's Venucia in exchange for being allowed to expand their own production.

The China Association of Automobile Manufacturers itself has projected 700,000 BEV sales in 2016.  
A single manufacturer (BYD) has projected its own sales to triple to 150,000.  (And as of 25 April BYD shares were holding up relatively well - suggesting that the market as a whole believes in the forecast). 
Tesla vehicles are hugely popular in Hong Kong and only just beginning to hit the streets on the mainland.

Some observations:
Total EV sales last year were reported as 331092
The first 10 months were reported at 171145 (http://www.caam.org.cn/AutomotivesStatistics/20151117/1305178647.html )
Jan+Feb 2015 EV sales were 12440
Jan+Feb 2016 EV reported sales were 35726
EV (new energy) numbers were reported on a monthly basis for most of the year, except separate reports for Nov and Dec appear to be absent.  Reporting seems to have switched to every other month after November's reports on October.

China seems to see a slow increase in EV sales each month. Continuing at the current rate would get us up to just over 50,000/month by December, with average monthly sales just barely too low to hit the 500,000 mark. However, if we think of this as a percentage increase rather than a linear increase, the numbers look better; they also look better when we consider the chance that the manufacturers will fudge those numbers just a bit to meet the government's goal. They do look worse if one predicts an economic collapse for China this year, but the market seems to be in the middle of crashing and people are still buying cars. I'm fairly optimistic here, and the presence of good data going forward makes me feel safe with a high prediction.
